CurrentSituation: Invoices and item details are checked manually, including expiration dates. Limited digital tools.
Phase1:
- Introduce barcode/QR scanning
- Centralize record-keeping in one spreadsheet/db
- Train Finance Director for automated PO approvals
- Upskill one in-house programmer with Python
Phase2:
- Integrate real-time cross-referencing tool for deliveries vs. POs
- Create dashboards/alerts for mismatches
Phase3:
- Implement predictive algorithms to flag high-risk deliveries
- Use ML for forecasting shortages or delays

CurrentSituation: Items inspected visually for damages and shelf-life. Near half-life items are rejected without data-based tracking.
Phase1:
- Record QC checks digitally (tablets/mobile)
- Basic color-coded alerts for near-expiry
- Finance Director learns basic automated checks
- In-house Python scripts for QC reporting
Phase2:
- Employ sensors/image recognition for automatic damage detection
- Link QC data to inventory records for auto-removal
Phase3:
- AI-driven QC with predictive maintenance
- Integrate computer vision for advanced anomaly detection

CurrentSituation: Manual entry for new items, scanning only for existing ones. High risk of errors.
Phase1:
- Standardize barcode formats
- Single system (spreadsheet or db) for all entries
- Finance Director approves POs quickly
- Python scripts automate batch uploads
Phase2:
- Sync with supplier databases in real time
- Simple data verification layer flags conflicts
Phase3:
- Predictive demand planning for stock entry
- Automated reorder suggestions (seasonality, promotions, history)

CurrentSituation: Items categorized manually, stored by broad product type, not optimized for quick retrieval.
Phase1:
- Assign digital shelf IDs
- Basic category list for consistent grouping
- Python helps build simple categorization scripts
Phase2:
- AI or rule-based system suggests optimal shelf placement based on demand frequency
- Barcode scanning tracks item movement
Phase3:
- Robotics or AI picking/packing
- Continuous shelf optimization (learning from picking patterns)

CurrentSituation: Manually tracked allocation to selling floor. Discrepancies between recorded vs. actual stock.
Phase1:
- Digital movement log/app to track each product leaving the stockroom
- Daily/weekly reconciliation
Phase2:
- Real-time tracking sensors (RFID) for automatic updates
- Dashboards highlight allocation discrepancies
Phase3:
- AI predicts replenishment needs per shelf
- Automated orders to maintain optimal floor stock

CurrentSituation: Items moved manually from stockroom to sales floor, no automated updates.
Phase1:
- Scan items to 'moved' or 'available' status
- Single shared db tracks location
- Finance Director sees large inbound shipments data
Phase2:
- Real-time scanning or RFID to monitor movement
- Notifications for urgent restock items
Phase3:
- Advanced analytics on item-flow patterns
- Automated dispatch signals for shelves nearing low stock

CurrentSituation: Shelves arranged mostly by category, but related items can be scattered.
Phase1:
- Create a simple classification scheme (brand/usage)
- Basic digital shelf map or planogram
- Capture sales data for future improvement
Phase2:
- AI-based product placement (based on sales)
- Auto-updating planograms as products change
Phase3:
- Real-time planogram optimization
- Shopper behavior heatmaps for granular product placement

CurrentSituation: Prices and promotions set by clerks' experience, often inconsistent.
Phase1:
- Centralize pricing in one system
- Finance Director training for price approvals
- Python scripts for bulk pricing updates
Phase2:
- Rule-based engine auto-applies discounts under conditions (stock age, inventory levels)
- Analytics dashboard to measure promo impact
Phase3:
- AI-driven dynamic pricing in real time
- Personalized offers based on purchase history

CurrentSituation: ~50,000 items, arrangement not aligned with demand or turnover efficiency.
Phase1:
- Track basic foot traffic or busy aisles
- Log top sellers by location in a spreadsheet
Phase2:
- Implement AI to identify high-traffic areas
- Digital signage/app notifications for cross-selling
Phase3:
- AR navigation or advanced store apps
- Real-time staff deployment based on foot traffic data

CurrentSituation: Barcodes used, but shared codes cause confusion. Daily reconciliations do not fully fix errors.
Phase1:
- Standardize barcode assignment (unique codes)
- POS software flags duplicate barcodes
Phase2:
- Advanced POS with image or weight checks
- Real-time inventory sync at checkout
Phase3:
- Cashierless or AI-based recognition
- Continuous engine refining mislabeled items

CurrentSituation: Informal feedback, no structured analysis. Hard to gather insights or improve.
Phase1:
- Encourage basic digital feedback forms
- Central place to log suggestions/complaints
Phase2:
- Data analytics on collected feedback
- Trend analysis for service improvement
Phase3:
- Predictive modeling for customer preferences
- Personalized recommendations or loyalty programs

CurrentSituation: Reorders depend on manual checks and periodic system suggestions, not real-time analytics.
Phase1:
- Basic scanning for low-stock items
- Finance Director approvals via a shared system
- Python scripts to highlight reorder thresholds
Phase2:
- Automated reordering suggestions via real-time sales & inventory data
- Supplier integration for immediate restock
Phase3:
- Fully AI-driven reorder triggers (forecast-based)
- Dynamic quantity adjustments factoring seasonality, promotions

CurrentSituation: Manual refunds require supervisor intervention, paper-based process.
Phase1:
- Simple digital form for returns (spreadsheet or basic tool)
- Basic rules for refund approvals
Phase2:
- Automated system with predefined approval rules
- Real-time updates to inventory upon refund
Phase3:
- Advanced data checks for fraudulent returns
- AI-based anomaly detection in refund patterns

Phase1:
- Short finance director training for automated PO sign-off
- Basic scanning to match barcodes vs. supplier docs
Phase2:
- Dynamic POs from real-time sales & stock analytics
- Enhanced barcode validation to minimize supplier errors
Phase3:
- ML-based supply chain optimization
- Automatic feedback loops for barcode inaccuracies
